courses.name: GEOG 2N, Section 001: Apocalyptic Geographies (22511--UP---P-GEOG----2N--------001-)
courses.syllabus_body:
Geography 2N-001: Apocalyptic Geographies: How can we prevent the end of the world?

Course Description:

It truly is the end of the world, as we know it. Throughout this course, we will explore different visions, imaginaries, and understandings of ending world(s) from a range of different positions and experiences. We will examine and critically analyze apocalyptic topics including nuclear war, climate change, market collapse, interplanetary expansion, and memes, among many other things. Our course will consider the mundane yet urgent nature of apocalypse today, how for many people in many places worlds have ended many times over and worlds are unraveling as we speak. We will learn to analyze and understand apocalypse as a story that we tell that serves certain social functions, such as justifying different institutional formations, consolidating power and authority, building senses of group identity in relation to imagined and actual ‘others,’ and working to naturalize and stabilize inequalities. We will also look at how apocalyptic stories have been used as a form of social critique to imagine more just and inclusive presents/futures.

Students will develop and employ critical and analytical thinking skills to engage a diversity of texts from the humanities (e.g., historical and literary accounts, graphic novels, films and other historical and contemporary media) and contemporary popular culture in order to situate these apocalyptic visions in particular historical, cultural, and political contexts. Students will utilize integrative thinking skills and an interdisciplinary geographic approach to connect these visions with contemporary social issues in order to consider how we might address these complex problems while imagining and actualizing alternative futures. Students will practice global learning, drawing on course material that engages U.S. and cross-cultural perspectives in recognition of the global reach of the interconnected social, economic, political, and cultural systems that shape humanity's shared fate. As an introductory geography course, we will engage with ideas spanning the gamut of human geography, gaining familiarity with political, urban, cultural, economic, historical, environmental and other approaches to geographic inquiry.  

Basic Information

Semester: Spring 2025

Professor: Mark Ortiz, PhD, Assistant Professor of Geography, mark.ortiz@psu.edu 

Teaching Assistant: F.M. Kim, FMKim@psu.edu 

Credit Hours: 3 Credit Lecture and Discussion

Lectures: MoWe, 2:30-3:20 PM, Hosler Building 026

*You are assigned to one of the four discussion groups based on your recitation section. See the table below to find your section, discussion group, and meeting time.

Office Hours: by appointment (in office or via zoom). The TA will make their own arrangements and communicate them to you during the first day of class. 

You can schedule an appointment at your convenience using my booking link: Book time with Ortiz, Mark

*A note on office hours. I don't like to schedule office hours because it ties me to sitting in my room for 16 hours and I will go an entire semester without seeing a student more than once. That said, I am usually in my office during normal working hours and I am generally quite glad to talk to students. If my door is open then please knock and come in. If you don't get to Walker that often then send me an email. I am almost always able to schedule something within 48 hours and often the same day. I am happy to talk to you in person or via zoom from the comfort of your own home.

A lot of people think you need to have a really good reason to talk to a professor in office hours. That is not true. Moreover, the University is using your tuition to pay me to be available to you, so feel empowered to take advantage of that time. Some things we could talk about:

  • Stuff in the readings or lectures
  • What major should you choose and why it is Geography,
  • How to figure out what to do when you grow up (grad school? careers?)
  • Other things

Where am I supposed to be and when?

Lecture: Monday and Wednesday, Hosler 026, 2:30-3:20 PM 

Recitation: Recitation sections will be led by your wonderful TA during the scheduled time.  Each discussion section has 25 students in it. Discussion sections are named after the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse. Your Four Horsemen name is only relevant for the purposes of Packback and for recitation activities. 

2D Conquest in Hosler 218A
 We 11:15AM - 12:05PM
3D Famine in Deike 341
 Fr 10:10 - 11:00AM
4D War in Walker 110
 Fr 1:25 - 2:15PM
8D Plague in Hosler 218A
 We 3:35-4:25PM 

What do I need to buy?

1 license for Packback to be used as a course discussion tool ($39). We will use this tool for written engagement in the course every week and it will account for a large portion of your grade. This should work seamlessly if you register and pay through the 'Packback' tab on the sidebar of this Canvas page. I am not sure how it will work if you buy through the bookstore though. If you go through the bookstore though I believe it can be paid for with financial aid. I also believe they have some scholarships available, so if the $39 feels like a lot make the ask---they are really trying to get a big PSU contract, so they want you all to be happy with the product.

Detailed Course Schedule

What am I going to be graded on?

  • Weekly written discussion via PackBack (30%) (12 Total Packback Posts)
  • Two (non-cumulative, online) exams on lecture content and reading assignments (20% Total - 10% each)
    • Midterm Exam: Wednesday, March 5
    • Final Exam: Monday, May 5
  • One short speculative or science fiction writing assignment (5%)
    • Due: Friday, April 18 
  • One Apocalyptic Geography Project: one 2-3 page essay (Total 20%, separated into stages), and an associated, short verbal presentation on your essay (10%). This project will be broken down into various checkpoints throughout the semester to receive feedback from peers and instructors and facilitate progress. 
    • Project Topic & Brief Outline (5%): Friday, February 7
    • First Draft (5%): Friday, March 28
    • Presentations (10%): Held in Recitation during Week 13
    • Final Draft (10%): Monday, April 28
  • Various activities completed in the recitation section (15%) 

The philosophy here is that engaging with the ideas in this class with your classmates is the best way to gain familiarity with what we are trying to accomplish. If we can't help you do that then we lose. We also want to give you a chance to structure your ideas more carefully (the independent assignments). The quizzes are relatively unimportant to discourage cheating (why bother) and downplay the importance of memorization while still giving you an incentive to do the work.

What do I need to do to get an A?

Final grades will be assigned using the following classification:

A   = 94-100%  |  A-  = 90-93% | B+  = 87-89% | B   = 84-86% | B-  = 80-83%

C+ = 77-79%    | C    = 70-76% | D    = 60-70% | F   = < 60%

I need an extension/ What is the policy on late assignments?

There are no extensions on the Packback assignments, but I will drop the lowest score (or you can choose to skip one). Packback is intended to work as an engagement tool. 'Engaging' after the fact isn't engaging. If you aren't allocating the time to engage with the material and your classmates during the week then you are not doing the core work of the class and your grade will reflect that. Since you can easily get full points on this assignment, there really is no excuse to not get it done.

Except for Packback, if you contact the instructor (mark.ortiz@psu.edu) any time before an assignment is due you can have an extension. You don't need to give a reason so don't sweat it. You don't need to hear back from me to be sure the extension is granted. I will get back to you so we can agree on a revised due date, but as long as I got the email before the assignment was due you are fine. I don't want to judge the quality of excuses so I will just trust you. We can work it out.

If you fail to contact the instructor before the assignment is due you probably* can't have an extension.

If you turn in an assignment late WITHOUT getting an extension you will receive a zero on the assignment. That's right, if you can't be bothered to send me a quick note asking for extra time then we can't be bothered to grade your work. Just ask for the extension, I wont think any less of you I promise.

*The way things are going I am no longer willing to use absolutes here, but you are really really really unlikely to get an extension.

Can I cheat?

No, of course not. See the text below on Academic Integrity. Something to particularly watch out for is using another person's words in the written assignments you turn in and in your questions and responses on Packback. I take these things seriously and will 1) Give you a zero on the assignment, and 2) Report you to the Dean's office for further action.

Some people copy and paste off the internet to avoid doing the work or just get AI to do their essay for them so they don't have to. These people are cheating and they know it. I have zero respect for people who are paying for an education but don't want to take the time to think about things--if this is you, you have lost the plot and need to rethink your goals in life. If you are honestly confused by the idea that taking other people's words and using them as your own or just having a chatbot write for you is cheating then I strongly suggest you come to office hours early in the term and I will walk you through it.

The biggest problem comes from people who are not trying to cheat, but are sloppy with their notes (writing down a quote from something they read but not putting it in quotes and then using the exact text in a paper later). A lot of these folks aren't trying to cheat, but it still counts as plagiarism. Here is a basic, foolproof rule to guide you: If an idea comes from a source, cite that source. If the words and idea come from a source put the words in quotes and cite the source. That is the rule. If you break that rule it is plagiarism. The good news is that using quotes and citations really impresses the grader, so the better you are at using these words and ideas properly the better you will do on the assignment. There is no reason to take someone else's ideas and not credit them.

After I say this I always get questions about what citation style to use. I have never understood why anyone cares. As long as it credits the author, gives the date the idea was published and provides enough information for me to get the source from the internet or a library I am good. For the sake of avoiding follow up questions from those who REALLY want an answer, APA.

Packback Questions

Participation is a requirement for this course, and the Packback Questions platform will be used for online discussion about class topics. Packback will be 30% of your grade, a high number, please be cognizant that this is because we think that asking questions about the material and trying to engage on those questions with your classmates is absolutely the most important thing you can do to learn the material.

Packback Requirements:

Your participation on Packback will count toward 30% of your overall course grade.

There will be a weekly Thursday 11:59 PM EST deadline for submitting a question.

There will be a Weekly Sunday at 11:59PM EST deadline for submitting two responses to questions raised by your classmates.

In order to receive your points per week, you should submit the following each week:

 1 open-ended Question per week with a minimum Curiosity Score of 70, each worth 3pts of each assignment grade

2 Responses per week with a minimum Curiosity Score of 70, each worth 1pt of each assignment grade

In past semesters students have run into problems where their post didn't go through because the curiosity score wasn't high enough or because it was moderated for content. Just keep an eye on things to make sure it is working properly for you and don't wait until the last minute to draw attention to problems. Also, there is an issue where people access Packback NOT through the link on Canvas. These people can see that their posts are going through and getting scored, but they don't show up as graded. I can fix this, but it is a lot of work. Just check the Gradebook after the first couple weeks to make sure things are working out.

How to Register on Packback:

Note: Only access Packback through Canvas in order to ensure your grades sync properly

  1. Click the Packback menu heading on the left side of the Canvas Page
  2. Follow the instructions on your screen to finish your registration.
  3. In order for your grade to be visible in Canvas, make sure to access Packback through Canvas, not directly through the packback web site

How to Get Help from the Packback Team:

If you have any questions or concerns about Packback throughout the semester, please read their FAQ at help.packback.coLinks to an external site.. If you need more help, contact their customer support team directly at help@packback.co.

 For a brief introduction to Packback Questions and why we are using it in class, watch this video:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OV7QmikrD68Links to an external site.

Packback is a discussion platform, therefore it is meant to incorporate back and forth between individuals. This means I will not grant extensions on Packback assignments a discussion where everyone but you has moved on is not a discussion. I will let you drop your lowest score though.

What else might I want to know?

All the details that PSU requires me to convey to you that no one ever asks about are below in nice fancy language. It is, obviously, your responsibility to familiarize yourself with this material.

Assistance with textbooks:

Penn State honors and values the socioeconomic diversity of our students. If you require assistance with the costs of textbooks for this course, contact the Office of Student Care and Advocacy (120 Boucke Building, 863-4926, http://studentaffairs.psu.edu/studentcareLinks to an external site.). For additional need related to socioeconomic status please visit http://sites.psu.edu/projectcahirLinks to an external site..

Course Goals and Objectives:

The primary objective of this course is to expose students to contemporary social issues in the United States and around the globe in order to develop student’s critical, analytical and integrative thinking while they learn how to engage with systems of governance, education, democratic participation, and individual and collective action. The ultimate objective is for participants to develop a deep and multidimensional understanding of human-environment relations, and the manifestation of human activity on the landscape

By taking this course, students will be able to:

  1. Interpret, discuss and compare texts and arguments in the social sciences and humanities, as evidenced through well-organized and clearly articulated verbal and written arguments;
  1. Analyze different cultural contexts, in the U.S. and abroad in a variety of textual materials, such as academic readings, film, novels, newspaper articles and art;
  1. Evaluate specific contemporary social issues, their causes, effects, and possible outcomes.

Course Content and Expectations:

See the modules visible on the course home page. See also the material above on the timing of assignments and expectations for their completion.

Required Course Policies and Statements:

Reporting Educational Equity Concerns:

Penn State takes great pride to foster a diverse and inclusive environment for students, faculty, and staff.  Acts of intolerance, discrimination, or harassment due to age, ancestry, color, disability, gender, gender identity, national origin, race, religious belief, sexual orientation, or veteran status are not tolerated (https://policy.psu.edu/policies/ad29Links to an external site.) and can be reported through Educational Equity via the Report Bias webpageLinks to an external site. (http://equity.psu.edu/reportbias/Links to an external site.). 

Assessment Policy:

See "What am I going to be graded on?" above.

Quizzes will be taken online during the scheduled class meeting. Students are expected to complete the quizzes during the class period. A make-up exam can be scheduled with the instructor at least 24 hours in advance of the exam.

Academic Integrity:

Students in this class are expected to write their discussion pieces individually, to work the exams on their own, and to write their papers in their own words using proper citations. Students are not to copy responses or exam answers from another person's paper and present them as their own; students may not plagiarize text from papers or websites written by others.  Students who present other people's work as their own will receive at least a 0 on the assignment and may well receive an F or XF in the course. 

Academic integrity is the pursuit of scholarly activity in an open, honest, and responsible manner. Academic integrity is a basic guiding principle for all academic activity at The Pennsylvania State University, and all members of the University community are expected to act in accordance with this principle.  

According to Penn State policy G-9: Academic IntegrityLinks to an external site., an academic integrity violation is “an intentional, unintentional, or attempted violation of course or assessment policies to gain an academic advantage or to advantage or disadvantage another student academically.” Unless your instructor tells you otherwise, you must complete all course work entirely on your own, using only sources that have been permitted by your instructor, and you may not assist other students with papers, quizzes, exams, or other assessments. You may not use ideas, images, or word phrases created by another person (e.g., from Course Hero or Chegg) or by generative technology, such as ChatGPT. You may not submit false or fabricated information, use the same academic work for credit in multiple courses, or share instructional content. Students with questions about academic integrity should ask their instructor before submitting work. 

 Students facing allegations of academic misconduct may not drop/withdraw from the affected course unless they are cleared of wrongdoing (see G-9: Academic IntegrityLinks to an external site.). Attempted drops will be prevented or reversed, and students will be expected to complete course work and meet course deadlines. Students who are found responsible for academic integrity violations face academic outcomes, which can be severe, and put themselves at jeopardy for other outcomes which may include ineligibility for Dean’s List, pass/fail elections, and grade forgiveness. Students may also face consequences from their home/major program and/or The Schreyer Honors College. 

 Please also see: Earth and Mineral Sciences Academic Integrity Procedures: https://www.ems.psu.edu/undergraduate/academic-integrity/academic-integrity-undergraduatesLinks to an external site., which this course adopts. To learn more, see Penn State’s “Academic Integrity Training for StudentsLinks to an external site..” 

Accommodations for Students with Disabilities  

Penn State welcomes students with disabilities into the University’s educational programs. Every Penn State campus has an office for students with disabilities. The Student Disability Resources (SDR) website provides contact information for every Penn State campus: (http://equity.psu.edu/student-disability-resources/campus-officesLinks to an external site.). For further information, please visit the Student Disability Resources website (http://equity.psu.edu/student-disability-resourcesLinks to an external site.). 

 In order to receive consideration for reasonable accommodations, you must contact the appropriate disability services office at the campus where you are officially enrolled, participate in an intake interview, and provide documentation: http://equity.psu.edu/student-disability-resources/applying-for-servicesLinks to an external site.. If the documentation supports your request for reasonable accommodations, your campus’s disability services office will provide you with an accommodation letter. Please share this letter with your instructors and discuss the accommodations with them as early in your courses as possible. You must follow this process for every semester that you request accommodations. 

Change in Normal Campus Operations  

Campus emergencies, including weather delays and closures, are announced on Penn State NewsLinks to an external site. and communicated to cell phones, email, the Penn State Facebook page, and Twitter via PSUAlert (sign up at: https://psualert.psu.edu/psualert/Links to an external site.).   

 Reporting Educational Equity Concerns  

Penn State takes great pride to foster a diverse and inclusive environment for students, faculty, and staff.  Acts of intolerance, discrimination, or harassment due to age, ancestry, color, disability, gender, gender identity, national origin, race, religious belief, sexual orientation, or veteran status are not tolerated (https://policy.psu.edu/policies/ad29Links to an external site.) and can be reported through Educational Equity via the Report Bias webpageLinks to an external site. (http://equity.psu.edu/reportbias/Links to an external site.). 

 Counseling and Psychological Services  

Many students at Penn State face personal challenges or have psychological needs that may interfere with their academic progress, social development, or emotional wellbeing.  The university offers a variety of confidential services to help you through difficult times, including individual and group counseling, crisis intervention, consultations, online chats, and mental health screenings.  These services are provided by staff who welcome all students and embrace a philosophy respectful of clients’ cultural and religious backgrounds, and sensitive to differences in race, ability, gender identity and sexual orientation.  Services include the following: 

 Counseling and Psychological Services at University Park  (CAPS)Links to an external site.: 814-863-0395 
Counseling and Psychological Services at Commonwealth CampusesLinks to an external site.  
Penn State Crisis Line (24 hours/7 days/week): 877-229-6400 
Crisis Text Line (24 hours/7 days/week): Text LIONS to 741741 

Attendance  

Regular attendance is critical for building the skills and knowledge developed throughout the class. Students who participate have a more complete understanding of the material presented and are more likely to succeed in the class. The University recognizes that, on exceptional occasions, students may miss a class meeting to participate in a regularly scheduled university-approved curricular or extracurricular activity (such as field trips, debate trips, choir trips, and athletic contests), or due to unavoidable or other legitimate circumstances such as illness, injury, military service, family emergency, religious observance, participation in local, state, and federal government elections, or post-graduate, career-related interviews when there is no opportunity for students to re-schedule these opportunities (such as elections or employment and graduate school final interviews).  In all cases, you should inform me in advance, when possible. Missing class, even for a legitimate purpose, may mean there is work that cannot be made up, hurting your grade in this class.  Students who encounter serious family, health, or personal situations that result in extended absences should contact the Office of the Assistant Vice President for Student Affairs (AVPSA) and Student Care and Advocacy for help:  http://studentaffairs.psu.edu/studentcareLinks to an external site..  You should be prepared to provide documentation for participation in University-approved activities, as well as for career-related interviews.  You should submit to the instructor a Class Absence Form: https://undergrad.psu.edu/aappm/class_absence_v3.pdfLinks to an external site., at least one week prior to the activity. 

Diversity, Inclusion, and Respect  

In EMS, inclusivity is one of our core values. We prioritize fostering a diverse and equitable community in which each member knows that they belong here and is inspired to succeed. We encourage everyone in our EMS community to be actively engaged with fostering this ideal, and all members of this class should contribute to a respectful, welcoming, and inclusive environment and interact with civility. Our commitment to inclusivity is in alignment with Penn State’s values and policies. 

To learn more, visit the EMS Educational Equity website https://www.ems.psu.edu/diversityLinks to an external site..  Here, you will find information about the EMS ALLWE initiative, the Rainbow EMS Network, Anti-Racism, active ally-ship, bystander intervention, and much more. The site also has resources for where to turn if you need assistance, as well as links to University references.  Also, contact your EMS department’s Associate Head for DEI for more information about department initiatives. 

Disclaimer Statement  

Please note that the specifics of this Course Syllabus can be changed at any time, and you will be responsible for abiding by any such changes. Changes to the syllabus shall be given to you in written (paper or electronic) form.  

Course Copyright  

All course materials students receive or to which students have online access are protected by copyright laws. Students may use course materials and make copies for their own use as needed, but unauthorized distribution and/or uploading of materials without the instructor’s express permission is strictly prohibited. University Policy AD 40, the University Policy Recording of Classroom Activities and Note Taking Services addresses this issue. Students who engage in the unauthorized distribution of copyrighted materials may be held in violation of the University’s Code of Conduct, and/or liable under Federal and State laws. 

For example, uploading completed labs, homework, or other assignments to any study site constitutes a violation of this policy. 

Penn State E-mail Accounts  

All official communications from Penn State are sent to students' Penn State e-mail accounts. Be sure to check your Penn State account regularly, or forward your Penn State e-mail (see https://pennstate.service-now.com/sp?id=kb_article&sys_id=e38bd12c6fb792807ae4677eae3ee441Links to an external site.https://pennstate.service-now.com/sp?id=kb_article_view&sys_kb_id=76e0cebc1bff90d413b599ba234bcbecLinks to an external site.) to your preferred e-mail account, so you don't miss any important information. 

Deferred Grades  

If you are prevented from completing this course within the prescribed amount of time for reasons that are beyond your control, it is possible to have the grade deferred with the concurrence of the instructor, following Penn State Deferred Grade Policy 48-40 (http://senate.psu.edu/policies-and-rules-for-undergraduate-students/47-00-48-00-and-49-00-grades/#48-40Links to an external site.). To seek a deferred grade, you must submit a written request (by e-mail or U.S. post) to the instructor describing the reason(s) for the request. Non-emergency permission for filing a deferred grade must be requested before the beginning of the final examination period. It is up to the instructor to determine whether or not you will be permitted to receive a deferred grade. If permission is granted, you will work with the instructor to establish a communication plan and a clear schedule for completion.  If, for any reason, the course work for the deferred grade is not complete by the assigned time, a grade of "F" will be automatically entered on your transcript. 

Military Personnel  

Veterans and currently serving military personnel and/or spouses with unique circumstances (e.g., upcoming deployments, drill/duty requirements, disabilities, VA appointments, etc.) are welcome and encouraged to communicate these, in advance if possible, to the instructor in the case that special arrangements need to be made. 

Technical Requirements  

For this course, we recommend the minimum technical requirements outlined on the World Campus Technical Requirements page (https://www.worldcampus.psu.edu/general-technical-requirementsLinks to an external site.), including the requirements listed for same-time, synchronous communications. If you need technical assistance at any point during the course, please contact the ITS Help Desk (http://itservicedesk.psu.eduLinks to an external site.). 

Netiquette  

The term "Netiquette" refers to the etiquette guidelines for electronic communications, such as e-mail and bulletin board postings. Netiquette covers not only rules to maintain civility in discussions, but also special guidelines unique to the electronic nature of forum messages. Please review some general Netiquette guidelinesLinks to an external site. that should be followed when communicating in this course. 

Disruptive Behavior  

Behavior that disrupts normal classroom activities will not be tolerated, in accordance with the Student Code of ConductLinks to an external site.. 

Safety  

In the event of an evacuation, we will follow posted evacuation routes and gather at the Designated Meeting Site.  Evacuation routes for all EMS buildings are available at https://www.ems.psu.edu/resources-faculty-and-staff/safety-and-emergency-information/emergency-management-planningLinks to an external site..  For more information regarding actions to take during particular emergencies, please see the Penn State Emergency Action GuidesLinks to an external site.. 

Mandated Reporting Statement  

Penn State’s policies require me, as a faculty member, to share information about incidents of sex-based discrimination and harassment (discrimination, harassment, sexual harassment, sexual misconduct, dating violence, domestic violence, stalking, and retaliation) with Penn State’s Title IX coordinator or deputy coordinators, regardless of whether the incidents are stated to me in person or shared by students as part of their coursework.  For more information regarding the University's policies and procedures for responding to reports of sexual or gender-based harassment or misconduct, please visit Penn State's Office of Sexual Misconduct Reporting & ResponseLinks to an external site. website. 

Additionally, I am required to make a report on any reasonable suspicion of child abuse in accordance with the Pennsylvania Child Protective Services LawLinks to an external site..

Required Text | Course Description & Objectives | Tentative Schedule | Course Requirements | Grading Policy | How Class Works |  Exam Policy | Makeup Policy | Campus Closure | Academic Integrity | Disability Policy | Educational Equity | Counseling and Psychological Services | 

Required Text and Materials

The text for this course is University Physics Volume 1 from OpenStax. Electronic copies are available for free at https://openstax.org/details/books/university-physics-volume-1. Print copies are available for purchase at the HUB bookstore.

Expert TA, a web-based homework program is required. Access to Expert TA requires registration using your @psu.edu email address. A link to this system's website is here https://login.theexpertta.com/Login.aspx). The system will not be accessible before January 11. The registration link is : https://reg.theexpertta.com/USQ40PA-EFB3BA-3E9 Payment to join this system is available as a web transaction through the Expert TA website and through purchase of an access code from the HUB bookstore. The first 14 days of the semester are available with full access as a free trial.

In addition you are also required to have a device which is compatible with Top Hat. Top Hat will be used for participation in your lecture sessions. You can find information about Top Hat at Penn state here. If you do not set up your Top Hat account, then you cannot earn a lecture participation grade (3% of the total course grade).
As office hours and help sessions may be held in Zoom, a Zoom compatible device may be helpful. Please see https://zoom.psu.edu/ for details on Zoom.

Finally, we highly recommend that you have a bound notebook in which you will solve all of your online homework problems. Good problem solving practice dictates writing out full solutions (with pictures and words explaining what you are doing) to every homework problem you do. Having a notebook specifically for this will encourage you to develop this important habit.

Course Description & Course Objectives

Course Description

Calculus-based study of the basic concepts of mechanics: motion, force, Newton's laws, energy, collisions, and rotation.

A detailed listing of lecture topics and a schedule of major course events may be found from the CANVAS home page.

Course Objectives

PHYS 211 is a General Education Course. It focuses on the General Education Learning Objectives of:

  1. EFFECTIVE COMMUNICATION 
  2. CRITICAL AND ANALYTICAL THINKING 
  3. KEY LITERACIES 
Upon completion of PHYS 211, students should be able to demonstrate a mastery of:
1. Relating position, velocity, acceleration and time using kinematics relationships
2. Using vectors
3. Forces and Newton’s Laws of Motion
4. Rotational Motion
5. Conservation laws
6. Oscillations 
A more detailed list of Learning Objectives for the course is linked from the home page
return to top of page

 Schedule

  • Schedule of reading assignments & lecture topics 
  • schedule for recitation and laboratory activities.
return to top of page

Course Requirements

Co-requisite: MATH 140

 *If during the semester you need to drop MATH 140, and have not previously passed it with a D, please contact your academic advisor for advice on how to proceed. You will not be allowed to remain in PHYS 211 unless you remain in MATH 140 until week 10.  At that time and through the Late Drop Deadline established by the Registrar you may complete a "Prerequisite Override Request" form in LionPATH with the justification "The Physics Department said I may drop MATH 140 and keep PHYS 211 at this time." The Physics Department will then receive that request and will approve it.*
return to top of page

Grading Policy

Your grade in the course will be based on your performance in the labs, in recitation, on the pre-lecture & problem set assignments, and on the exams with the following weights:

Course Component Weight
Exams Midterm 1 15%
Midterm 2 15%
Midterm 3 15%
Final 18%
Recitation Activities 10%
Laboratory Activities 10%
Expert TA Pre-Class 5%
Homework (Post-Class) 9%
Class Participation 3%
Extra Credit SEEQ Response Rate 1%
Welcome Survey 1%

Final letter grades for the course will be based on an absolute scale. The final course score will be rounded to the nearest integer. No curving of any kind will be employed. However, if the combined average exam score for the class (computed as the combined average of all midterm and final exams taken to date) is less than 70%, the grades on the most recent exam will be adjusted by additively raising the exam scores to allow the combined exam average to meet the target minimum of 70%.

The break points for the various grade levels are:

93% ≤ A ≤ 100%
90% ≤ A- < 93%
87% ≤ B+ < 90%
83% ≤ B < 87%
80% ≤ B- < 83%
77% ≤ C+ < 80%
70% ≤ C < 77%
60% ≤ D < 70%
0% ≤ F < 60%


You are responsible for verifying all of your scores (with the exception of the final exam score) before the final exam for the course.

  • Recitation and Laboratory Activities: Each category's score is calculated as the average of the scores of all of the activities of the appropriate type; all assignments are weighted equally, and none are omitted from this average. In the event that a student must miss a Recitation or Laboratory for one of the reasons the University allows makeup work for, they may request a makeup by completing the form on the homepage in Canvas. The score on the activity will be entered as a zero and then updated once the makeup is completed. See the Makeup Policy for more information.
  • Expert TA Activities
    • Pre-Class Assignments: The pre-class assignments are in Expert TA and are intended to help you prepare for the coming class. The pre-class score is calculated as the average of the score on each pre-class assignment; all assignments are weighted equally, and none are omitted from this average.
      Each assignment's score is calculated as either 100 (if the score in Expert TA is 75% or higher) or (100/75) × (points earned on assignment / total points possible on assignment) (if the score in Expert TA is below 75%).
      Multiple submissions are allowed for most questions. On multiple choice questions, on each submission after the first, credit will decrease by 100%/(# of answer options – 1).
    • Homework (Post-Class) Assignments: The homework score is calculated as the average of the scores of each post-class assignment; all assignments are weighted equally, and none are omitted from this average.
      Each assignment's score is calculated as either 100 (if the score in Expert TA is 90% or higher) or (100/90) × (points earned on assignment / total points possible on assignment) (if the score in Expert TA is below 90%).
      Multiple submissions are allowed for most questions. On multiple choice questions, on each submission after the first, credit will decrease by 100%/(# of answer options – 1). 
    • The purpose of the boosts are to allow students who work on problems and make small mistakes to still earn full credit. Using online resources for assistance  (Chegg, ChatGTP, etc) is cheating yourself and could be an academic integrity violation-- assignments are designed to help you prepare for exams, and using online resources will not help you prepare for exams.
    • Work submitted between the "Due" and "End" times will be eligible for 50% maximum partial credit. This work is still scaled according to the policies above.
  • Class Participation: 
    Each day you can earn one point for Class Participation through the use of Top Hat. To earn the full point you must answer >50% of the Top Hat questions on that day. There are more points available than are needed for a full score. To earn a full score for Class Participation, you must attend, and participate in, at least three-fourths of the classes.  The first week of class of Top Hat is "tech week" it  is not for credit but will be posted to check your registration.

  • Extra credit: There will be two opportunities to earn extra credit:
    • Welcome Survey: During the first week of class we have a welcome survey to learn more about who is in Physics 211 this semester and to get you started on a positive note. This is worth 1% extra credit.
    • SEEQ Response Rate: If four-fifths of the class (80%) completes the Student Educational Experience Questionnaire (SEEQ) when it is administered by the University, every student will be awarded 1% additional extra credit.

 

How Class Works

return to top of page

There are a number of parts of this course and it is useful to understand their purpose and how they fit together. First of all, we have several types of learning objectives: conceptual understanding skills, problem solving skills, experimental skills, group work skills. You will have multiple assessments of these skills, both formative (designed primarily to help you and the instructors see what you know during the learning process) and summative (designed primarily to grade your mastery of material after instruction on a topic is "complete"). There will also be activities designed to introduce you to the learning objectives and to help answer questions that you may have about them. 

Using those definitions, here are the class activities and their purposes:

Activity Primary Goals Notes
Reading Introduction: concepts, problem solving
Pre-Class Expert TA Assignments Formative: concepts, problem solving "Tests" material BEFORE class
Lecture  Formative: concepts, problem solving, class participation questions
Recitation Introduction: group skills; Formative & Summative: concepts, problem solving, group skills
Lab Introduction: experimental skills; Formative & Summative: concepts, problem solving, experimental skills, group skills
Post-Class Expert TA Assignments Summative: concepts, problem solving Try doing this closed book
Midterm Exams Summative: concepts, problem solving, experimental skills Primarily focused on previous material
Final Exam Summative: concepts, problem solving, experimental skills Broadly covers all class material

 

Lecture/TopHat

You must attend the "lecture" section for which you are registered (Top Hat participation in a lecture you are not registered for will not be counted for a grade). Your "lecture" section is the PHYS 211 section number which is not followed by a letter. During "lecture" class sessions you will have the opportunity to ask questions about the reading and will get practice answering conceptual questions (using Top Hat) and solving problems. Participation during class is not only expected but is also crucial for learning the material. Make sure you are using the WiFi and not Data in the classroom for TopHat to work best.

Laboratories

Laboratory sections meet for about 2 hours once a week in 312 or 306 Osmond. Your meeting time is determined by your section; your Laboratory section is the  PHYS 211 section number which is followed by an "L." You must attend the laboratory section in which you are registered — no switching is permitted. Please remember to sign the sign-in sheet to assure your attendance is marked.

During the lab session, your group will prepare a single write-up, addressing specific points of the experiments. Grading is based on participation, clear communication (quality explanations, clear graphs etc), and physics content. This write-up must be submitted with all group participants names on Canvas before the end of the laboratory session. If you do not help/participate you will not get the same grade. Make sure your work is represented in the document. For clarity also upload a text submission to canvas stating the names of your lab partners for each lab you attend.

Recitation

Recitation sections meet once a week for 50 minutes. Your meeting time is determined by your section; your Recitation section is the PHYS 211 section number which is followed by an "R." You must attend the recitation section in which you are registered – NO switching is permitted.

In these sections you will work collaboratively in three-member groups to complete problem-solving exercises. These problem solving activities are an invaluable component of learning physics, and will provide you with much more opportunity to explore problem solving techniques than you will have in class.

The recitation activities are available in the Recitations page in Canvas. Each group must begin with a blank copy of the activity and complete it during the class period. While only one paper is turned in via Canvas upload, every student should bring an individual copy of the pertinent activity to the recitation section to have later for study purposes. Alternatively, keep an electronic copy for your reference. This write-up must be submitted  with all  group participants names on Canvas at the end of class (within 15 minutes). If you do not help/participate you will not get the same grade. Make sure your work is represented in the document. 

At each recitation session it is the responsibility of each student to write their own name on the recitation document to be handed in for credit and to write their initials on the the attendance sign-in sheet.  We also highly recommend you leave a submission in Canvas assignment with your partner's names. 

The recitation and labs will be graded for participation and communication (100 points), and correctness (50 points). There are three roles for recitations: Recorder, Leader, and Checker. The Recorder writes on the paper - this job must rotate. Leader makes sure everyone contributing and leads discussion. Checker asks the TA questions and double checks the answers. You are expected to work on the recitation and labs the entire class time, and thus won't be penalized for incomplete activities if time runs out. Likewise you should aim to be on time as tardiness may prevent you from entering the classroom and is not a valid reason for a makeup.

Weekly Expert TA problem sets

There will typically be three Expert TA (https://login.theexpertta.com/Login.aspx) problem set assignments per week, two "pre-class" assignments (covering the required reading) due at 11:59pm on the night before each lecture (Sunday and Thursday) and one "post-class" assignment due. The due date and time for each Expert TA assignment appears in Canvas and Expert TA.
This system allows you to submit your homework at any time. Your grade on each assignment will be available immediately and, in most cases, you will have multiple tries to arrive at the correct answer. Students are encouraged to work together and collaborate on problem set assignments. Work submitted for individual assessment must be the work of the individual student. 
An important note about the difficulty and type of problems:  Post-class problems are designed to test your problem solving abilities, and in particular to assess your ability to solve hard problems. Similarly, recitation questions are structured to build upon each other, going into greater depth in a single topic (but with more "scaffolding" -- helpful hints). Thus questions on these assignments of a type that cannot be tested during the time-limited multiple choice midterm and final exams. This means that when compared to each other, although covering similar concepts and skills, these questions, and exam questions (and class participation questions) will not all look the same. We will provide sample exams which have qualitatively similar questions to the kinds of questions you should expect on your midterms. However, most midterm questions you will never have seen on any other assignment in the class. Being able to answer "new" questions (covering concepts and requiring skills that you have developed on formative assessments throughout the class) is a fundamental learning objective for the course.
return to top of page

Exam Policy

There will be three Midterm exams and a Final exam. Exams will be closed book. Relevant physical constants and formulae will be provided. Calculators are allowed. Cell phones, any other communication devices, tablet computers, and organizers, and additional paper are not allowed. 
 
The exams will be based on the assigned reading in the textbook, the material covered in lecture, the recitations, the laboratories, and the homework assignments. The majority of each exam, including the final, will cover most recent material, however physics is highly cumulative so some concepts and techniques will naturally be tested on multiple exams. Please see the Course Content Objectives and the Exam pages from the Home page in Canvas for more information about the content assessed on the exams in this course.
return to top of page

Makeup and Excuse Policy

Examinations

All students should plan to take their exams at the scheduled times. However, in the event of a conflict between an exam and a University activity, students may request a Conflict Exam as discussed below. Students that are physically unable (e.g. due to illness or weather conditions) to take the exam at the regularly scheduled time should not attempt to take the exam (once an examination is taken, its result is final); those students may request a Makeup Exam as discussed below.

Conflict Exams: Conflict exams will be offered for valid reasons as per Penn State policy 44-35) conflict exams are to be requested by completing the form on the appropriate exam page in Canvas. Students can request Conflict Exams for Midterms by  emailing Prof. Drew (krp15@psu.edu) only if a student is unable to schedule an exam during the allotted time period.  Midterm Exam makeups will be computer-based exams taken in the Pollock Testing Center and must be scheduled with the course administrator. Students are not to self-enroll in an exam at the Pollock Testing Center. Students must request Conflict Exams for the Final by using the Registrar's form; late requests cannot be accommodated.

Makeup Exams: In the case of sudden or unexpected events that will cause them to miss an exam, students are required to notify the course instructor prior to the exam or as soon as is reasonably possible. Students that are physically unable (e.g. due to illness) to take the exam at the regularly scheduled time should not attempt to take the exam (once an examination is taken, its result is final). Makeup Exams should be taken no later than three business days after being able to return to classwork; students that do not take the exam within a reasonable time frame may receive a zero for the exam. Barring emergencies, only one makeup opportunity is granted for each exam. Midterm Exam makeups will be computer-based exams taken in the Pollock Testing Center and must be scheduled with the course administrator. Students are not to self-enroll in an exam at the Pollock Testing Center.

 

Laboratory and Recitation
The laboratory and recitation components of this course are structured around collaborative learning. You must be present in laboratory or recitation to do these assignments. Up to three (3) activities (labs and/or recitations) may be made up for a student throughout the entire course for University-approved reasons. More than three absences from activities at their regular times will interfere excessively with student learning. In extreme circumstances in which a student has four or more absences to be made up, he or she must contact the course administrator directly to discuss the situation as soon as possible. If you are absent from a laboratory or recitation section with a valid excuse, as described under "Valid Excuse Policy", fill out the Makeup Request form in Canvas within one week of the absence.  Your score for the missed activity will be recorded as a zero until the activity is made up. If you are absent without a valid excuse, a score of zero will be recorded for that assignment. If a student is more than ten minutes late to a recitation or lab, leaves before their group is done, or is gone for more than ten minutes during the activity they cannot receive any credit for that period and this is NOT a valid excuse to request a makeup; if you would be late due to a reason that is a University approved reason (e.g. illness), you may request a makeup activity.
Expert TA
You must complete the Problem sets as scheduled. They are available early so no excuses are accepted. Even technical glitches are not valid excuses. Importantly, that means please don't try to submit at 11:58PM for an 11:59PM deadline, as occasionally internet connections may lag. As mentioned above there is a window available for partial credit of Expert TA assignments. Because problem sets are available at least a week before the due date and can be done in advance, NO excuses are allowed.
Valid Excuse Policy

There are several valid reasons for missing course activities (labs & recitations or exams). All other reasons are not valid (including travel):

  • Illness (please don't come to lab/recitation/exam if you are sick!)
  • Family emergencies, including a death in the immediate family, death of a close friend, sudden hospitalization of a close family member, and events of similar gravity
  • University-approved curricular and extra-curricular activities; to obtain a makeup, a student needs to obtain a letter (or a class absence form) from the unit or department sponsoring the activity. The letter must indicate the anticipated absence dates, and it must be emailed to the course administrator before the first absence.
  • Religious holidays (must be submitted in advance)

 Missing a laboratory or recitation due to an examination in another course is not considered a valid excuse. Please schedule a makeup/conflict exam for your other course.

You have one week from the absence to submit a makeup request (less time right before each makeup period); otherwise it may be denied, barring extenuating circumstance (e.g., no access to the Internet due to reason for absence, such as an extended hospitalization).  All sign ups must be submitted through the Makeup/Conflict Form (linked from the CANVAS home page under "Request Forms").  Requests to make up or be excused due to reasons that are based on false claims is cheating and will be treated as described in the Academic Integrity Policy.

 

return to top of page

Campus Closure Policy:

Students can sign up for the University's emergency notification system PSUAlert. The University uses this system to announce campus closures (e.g. due to weather). Should the University Park campus be closed, this applies to all courses; announcements will be made in Canvas to describe how campus closures will affect PHYS 211 and will include information on how to proceed. Be sure to keep prevailing conditions in mind to safeguard your health and safety.

In the event of a weather-related, or similar, campus closure, you will still be responsible for learning material that would otherwise be missed due to weather. Please do not email your instructors, we will post instructions on canvas. In particular:

  • If there is a 2 hour delay:
    • on a Monday or Friday, all lectures will be cancelled and an announcement will be made on how you will still be able to learn the missed material
    • and your lab or recitation is cancelled, look to Canvas for instructions for make-up opportunities.
  • If class is cancelled for an entire day:
    • Again look to Canvas for instructions on how to proceed with learning the material from that day.
return to top of page

 

Academic Integrity

Academic integrity is the pursuit of scholarly activity in an open, honest and responsible manner. Academic integrity is a basic guiding principle for all academic activity at The Pennsylvania State University, and all members of the University community are expected to act in accordance with this principle. Consistent with this expectation, the University’s Code of Conduct states that all students should act with personal integrity, respect other students’ dignity, rights and property, and help create and maintain an environment in which all can succeed through the fruits of their efforts.

Simply put, don't cheat, don't share your work, don't ask others to do work for you (online or in person) and don't plagiarize. If you think you are doing something wrong, you probably are. We take academic integrity very seriously. There are many ways to get help in this course and we hope you do contact any member of the instructional team if you feel unsure about the material and worry about your grade. Our goal is for you to learn the material and succeed in the course. Everyone can get an A and we are ready to help any students that struggle.  Specifically, using online resources like Chat GTP, generative AI, or Chegg, UnstuckAI, etc to help you with classwork (especially during class) could be an academic integrity violation and could result in a negative impact to your grade. All labs, recitation, lecture notes, homework, are subject to copywrite and uploading/sharing this content without the university's consent is subject to copywrite violation laws as well.

In exchange for your hard work, participation and academic integrity we promise to create the best learning environments that we can and to help you as much as we can. There will be many opportunities for help and we are fair to all students. Collaborations and discussions among the students are strongly encouraged (they help learning) but we expect your best efforts to individually learn the material and we expect honesty and academic integrity in all aspects of the course.

 

return to top of page

Disability Policy

Penn State welcomes students with disabilities into the University's educational programs. Every Penn State campus has an office for students with disabilities. Student Disability Resources (SDR) Web site provides contact information for every Penn State campus: http://equity.psu.edu/sdr/disability-coordinator. For further information, please visit Student Disability Resources Web site: http://equity.psu.edu/sdr.

In order to receive consideration for reasonable accommodations, you must contact the appropriate disability services office at the campus where you are officially enrolled, participate in an intake interview, and provide documentation: http://equity.psu.edu/sdr/guidelines. If the documentation supports your request for reasonable accommodations, your campus’s disability services office will provide you with an accommodation letter. Please share this letter with your instructors and discuss the accommodations with them as early in your courses as possible. You must follow this process for every semester that you request accommodations.

return to top of page

Educational Equity and Bias Reporting

Penn State takes great pride to foster a diverse and inclusive environment for students, faculty, and staff. Acts of intolerance, discrimination, or harassment due to age, ancestry, color, disability, gender, gender identity, national origin, race, religious belief, sexual orientation, or veteran status are not tolerated and can be reported through Educational Equity via the Report Bias webpage

return to top of page

Counseling and Psychological Services

Many students at Penn State face personal challenges or have psychological needs that may interfere with their academic progress, social development, or emotional wellbeing. The university offers a variety of confidential services to help you through difficult times, including individual and group counseling, crisis intervention, consultations, online chats, and mental health screenings. These services are provided by staff who welcome all students and embrace a philosophy respectful of clients’ cultural and religious backgrounds, and sensitive to differences in race, ability, gender identity and sexual orientation.

Counseling and Psychological Services at University Park  (CAPS): 814-863-0395

Counseling and Psychological Services at Commonwealth Campuses

assignments.name: Apocalyptic Geography Project Topic & 'Outline'
assignments.description:
To get you thinking about your Apocalyptic Geography project, your task is to begin brainstorming a topic and building a brief ‘outline’ of what you think your paper will look like. As a reminder, for your project, your task is to choose an event, video game, film, book, song, or other piece of media and analyze its apocalyptic geography in 2-3 pages. You will also deliver a verbal presentation of your project using a single slide during your recitation section later in the semester.

At this stage, we want you to consider the following questions as you brainstorm a topic and begin to connect the dots of your paper:  

  • What kind of apocalypse(s) are you interested in?  
  • Is there a particular event, story, video game, show, film, song, or other piece of media you would like to focus on for your project?  
  • What do you think your choice of apocalypse story ‘unveils’ or reveals about ethics, institutions, and/or society?  
  • Given what you’re learning about geographic concepts (e.g., scale, relation, space, place etc.), what is one geographic idea that you think is relevant to your apocalypse of choice? How do you see this idea as relevant?  

At this point, you should aim to put together 1 paragraph that clearly answers these questions. This will be the basis for building your apocalyptic geography paper and presentation step by step. Your grade for this first step in the project will be 5% of your final grade, so please give this some thought. Thoughtful engagement with the questions will be rewarded with full credit and will make sure you stay on track with your primary project for the semester.

assignments.name: Exam 1 2/20
assignments.description:
Exam is on Thursday, 2/20, in our regular classroom. Exams will be passed out at 9:00 (5 minutes early) and are expected to be turned in at 10:20 p.m.  I teach another class at 10:35 and need to leave on time.

You need a calculator for the exam, are expected to give a numeric answer when applicable but do not have to show each step of a calculation. When applicable, you are expected to show work for full credit, that is, how did you get your answer, 

You may bring an 8.5 x 11 sheet of paper with memory items. Additionally, you may bring a copy of the named distribution sheet.

The exam covers chapters 1, Sections 2.1 - 2.3, and simulation for simple probabilities.

 

From the detail learning targets:

  1. General probability (Basic probability concepts)
    1. Define set functions, Venn diagrams, sample space and events. Define probability as a set function on a collection of events and state the basic axioms of probability.
    2. Calculate probabilities using addition and multiplication rules.
    3. Define independence and calculate probabilities of independent events.
    4. Calculate probabilities of mutually exclusive events.
    5. Define and calculate conditional probabilities.
    6. Calculate probabilities using combinatorics, such as combinations and permutations.
    7. State and understand situations that would use the Bayes Theorem and the law of total probability and use them to calculate conditional probabilities.
    8. Simple simulations using continuous uniform random variable.
  2. Univariate Random Variables (understand key concepts concerning discrete and continuous univariate random variables (including binomial, negative binomial, geometric, hypergeometric, Poisson, uniform, exponential, gamma, normal, and mixed) and their applications.)
    1. Explain and apply the concepts of random variables, probability and probability density functions, cumulative distribution functions.
    2. Calculate conditional probabilities.
    3. Explain and calculate expected value, mode, median, percentile, and higher moments.
    4. Explain and calculate variance standard deviation
    5. Define moment generating functions and use them to calculate distributions and moments.
    6. Apply transformations (Discrete and Continuous)
    7. Determine the sum of independent random variables (Normal)
    8. Simulation using a continuous uniform random variable (0,1) and the cumulative distribution function, F(x).
